docs.lead_paragraph: The number of people who get insurance this year through the Affordable Care Act’s public marketplaces is expected to be 13 million, down from a prior projection of 21 million.

headline.main: Budget Office Sharply Cuts Health Exchange Estimate
headline.print_headline: Budget Office Sharply Cuts Health Exchange Estimate

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office estimates that 13 million people will get health insurance through Affordable Care Act's public marketplaces in 2016, sharp reduction from its previous estimate of 21 million; also lowers its estimate of number of people who will receive subsidies, from 15 million, to 11 million a month.
docs.snippet: The number of people who get insurance this year through the Affordable Care Act’s public marketplaces is expected to be 13 million, down from a prior projection of 21 million.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: In trying to win the Iowa caucuses in a race that has become much tougher than she expected, Mrs. Clinton has tried to be more open and personable with Iowans.

headline.main: Hillary Clinton, Battling in Iowa, Turns Warm Under Pressure
headline.print_headline: For Crunchtime in Iowa, Clinton Loosens Up

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, facing unexpected headwinds in Democratic primary campaign, appears to be loosening up, as she did in 2008 campaign; she has begun to be more involved with, and friendlier to, Iowa voters ahead of caucuses.
docs.snippet: In trying to win the Iowa caucuses in a race that has become much tougher than she expected, Mrs. Clinton has tried to be more open and personable with Iowans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years in, it’s clear that progress in reducing the rate of the uninsured is going to be slower than proponents hoped. But the news isn’t all bad.

headline.main: Budget Office Lowers Its Forecast for Obamacare Enrollment

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid a rising tide of older adults, there are fewer specialists to treat them. Most residents would rather do something else.

headline.main: As Population Ages, Where Are the Geriatricians?

docs.abstract: Number of geriatricians across United States is shrinking even as need for specialty grows, driven by longer lifespans; popularity of field, one of lowest-paying speciaities in medicine, has fallen, with some doctors arguing geriatricians are unnecessary; experts say Medicare's low reimbursement rates make sustaining a geriatric practice difficult.
docs.snippet: Amid a rising tide of older adults, there are fewer specialists to treat them. Most residents would rather do something else.

docs.lead_paragraph: Few of the modern complaints about American health care are really new, the historian Nancy Tomes writes in her book.
docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger reviews book Remaking the American Patient: How Madison Avenue and Modern Medicine Turned Patients Into Consumers by Nancy Tomes.
docs.snippet: Few of the modern complaints about American health care are really new, the historian Nancy Tomes writes in her book.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers are starting to acknowledge that addiction is a problem that knows no racial barriers.
docs.abstract: Editorial endorses Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act, bill pending in both houses that would shore up drug treatment across country, reform prescription practices and begin pushing back against national drug epidemic; welcomes Congressional support for more rational, less punitive drug policies, noting change has been spurred by heroin and painkiller crisis that is increasingly claiming American lives.
docs.snippet: Lawmakers are starting to acknowledge that addiction is a problem that knows no racial barriers.
